title: 103_hr629
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Improvement of Information Access Act of 1993". The Congress recognizes the importance of a well-informed citizenry, access to government information, and the use of modern technology for citizens' benefit. Government information is considered a national resource and valuable economic asset. Government information is a national resource and valuable economic asset that belongs to the public. Taxpayers fund the creation of this information and should not have to pay excessive fees to access it. Difficulty in providing feedback to Federal agencies hinders public interest consideration in managing information resources. Federal agencies have been slow in developing standards for record and file formats, software query command structures, and timely access to Government information products and services at reasonable costs. SEC. 3. IMPROVED PUBLIC ACCESS TO GOVERNMENT INFORMATION. Amends Title 44, United States Code by adding a new chapter on information dissemination policies and practices. Sec. 4101 requires executive departments and establishments to annually report their information dissemination policies, including plans for new products and services. The department or establishment must report on plans for new information products and services, efforts to develop standards for information accessibility, progress in creating indexes and bibliographies, and methods for public access. The department or establishment must report on coordinated efforts with other agencies, methods for public access to information, provisions for protecting access to outdated records, methods for public awareness of information resources, services, and products, and a summary of public comments and department responses. Each year, executive departments, military departments, and independent establishments must publish a notice in the Federal Register and other platforms informing the public about the availability of a report on information dissemination policies. The public is given a 90-day period to submit comments on these policies. The public can comment on the information dissemination policies and practices of departments or establishments, including types of information collected, methods of dissemination, pricing, and validity. The public can comment on the information dissemination policies and practices of departments or establishments, including validity, reliability, timeliness, and usefulness to the public. Comments received will be available for public inspection, and there will be opportunities for dialogue between agency officials and the public through hearings and informal forums. Before discontinuing an information product or service, an agency must publish a notice in the Federal Register or through other means, allowing a 120-day period for public comments on the discontinuation, provide reasons for the discontinuation, and consider the comments received. Each agency must disseminate information through diverse modes and outlets to meet statutory requirements and provide broad public access. The information should be timely, useful, and reliable. The government must disseminate information in a timely, useful, and reliable manner, using standardized formats and distribution channels to ensure free or low-cost public access. Agencies are prohibited from charging depository libraries for distributing information products and services. The government is prohibited from charging depository libraries for distributing information products and services. Agencies cannot charge more than the incremental cost of distributing information, and they cannot charge any royalty or fee for the use or redissemination of government information. The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for agencies to provide access to public records within a specified timeframe upon request. The establishment of a period for agencies to provide public documents upon request by mail is added to title 44, United States Code. SEC. 4. STANDARDS FOR ACCESS TO PUBLIC RECORDS.

The Archivist of the United States and the Director of the National Institute of Standards and Technology will issue model performance standards for providing access to agency records under section 4101(f) of title 44, United States Code within one year of the enactment of this Act.
